review.title: A Scalable Multiclass Algorithm for Node Classification
review.abstract: We introduce a scalable algorithm, MUCCA, for multiclass node classification in weighted graphs. Unlike previously proposed methods for the same task, MUCCA works in time linear in the number of nodes. Our approach is based on a game-theoretic formulation of the problem in which the test labels are expressed as a Nash Equilibrium of a certain game. However, in order to achieve scalability, we find the equilibrium on a spanning tree of the original graph. Experiments on real-world data reveal that MUCCA is much faster than its competitors while achieving a similar predictive performance.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Classification of networked data is a fairly attractive field with applications in the fields of computer vision, bioinformatics, spam detection and text categorization. In recent years, networked data has become increasingly important due to the growing importance of social networks and other web-related applications, and this growing interest is pushing researchers to find scalable algorithms for important practical applications of these problems. In this paper, we focus our attention on a task called node classification, which is often studied in the semi-monitored environment of Zhu et al. [2003]. Recently, several teams have examined the problem from a theoretical perspective with interesting results, for example Cesa-Bianchi et al. [2009, 2010, 2011] developed on-line fast predictors for weighted and unweighted graphs, and Herbster et al. developed different versions of the Perceptron algorithm to classify the nodes of a graph (Herbster et al. [2009], Herbster and Pontil 2006].

We expect our graph to respect an idea of regularity, where neighboring nodes often have the same designation: this term of regularity is called homophily. Most machine learning algorithms for node classification (Autbster et al. [2009], Cesa-Bianchi et al. [2003], Cesa-Bianchi et al. [2011], adopt this bias and use it to improve their performance. sections.heading: 5.1.1 Datasets
sections.text: We select two real and known datasets to generate our diagrams: USPS and RCV1. USPS is a set of handwritten digits collected by the United States Postal Service and contains 9298 16 x 16 pixel (grayscale) images; the data set called RCV1 is a subset of 10,000 articles in chronological order taken from Reuters Corpus (a huge collection of messages published by Reuters Corpus). All articles were pre-processed with TF-IDF. Both datasets were natively multiclass, so we tested our binary predictors using a standard one-on-rest scheme. We have 10 binary experiments for USPS and 4 binary experiments for RCV1. We created our diagrams with as many nodes as the total number of examples for each dataset, using only 10 closest neighbors for each node (prior to symmetry).

sections.heading: 5.1.2 Experimental results
sections.text: The results shown in Table 1 are not conclusive, but we can observe some interesting trends: • GTG-ESS is the most accurate algorithm, but its computational complexity does not make it particularly suitable for most current practical applications. • MUCCA's accuracy is good and it is always close or better to SHAZOOs. • LABPROP approaches competitors when the size of the training set grows.

sections.heading: 5.2 Multiclass classification
sections.text: In the multiclass comparison we have replaced RCV1 with two other datasets, because it is not only multiclass, but also multi-label (an element has more than one label).As we explained earlier, SHAZOO only works on binary problems, so the only scalable competitor in this section is WMV.

sections.heading: 5.2.1 Datasets
sections.text: • USPS is the same graph we used for binary classification. • CARDIO consists of measurements of the characteristics of fetal heart rate (FHR) and uterine contraction (UC) on cardiotograms classified by experienced obstetricians. We created a graph based on the characteristic vectors, as we did for USPS and RCV1. The graph consists of 2126 nodes and 13696 edges. The nodes are divided into 3 classes (fetal states) 1. • GHGRAPH is a graph created from data published by Github.com for its 2009 competition. Each node represents a repository and an edge, meaning that a developer works on both repositories connected by this edge. If more than one developer works on these repositories, the number of developers used as weight for this edge is the most common repository used in this repository.

sections.heading: 5.2.2 Experimental results
sections.text: The results of our experiments shown in Table 2 are not conclusive, but we can observe some interesting trends: • It is not really clear which between GTG-ESS and LABPROP is the most accurate algorithm, but nevertheless MUCCA is always competitive with them. • MUCCA is always much better than WMV. As expected, WMV works better on "not too sparse" graphs like GHGRAPH, but even in this case it is surpassed by MUCCA. • The temporal complexity of GTG-ESS and LABPROP did not allow us to perform them in a reasonable time with our computing resources.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions and future work
sections.text: We introduced a novel scalable algorithm for classifying multi-class nodes in arbitrarily weighted graphs. In practice, MUCCA even works well in binary problems with competitors such as Label Propagation and SHAZOO, which are specifically designed for the binary environment. Several questions remain open. For example, committees of MUCCA predictors work well, but we do not know if there are better ways to act on their predictions. Given their common game theory background, it would also be interesting to investigate possible links between committees of MUCCA predictors and ESG-ECCA predictors.

In the binary classification case, algorithms based on min-cut have been proposed in the past (for example Blum and Chawla [2001]). Generalizing this approach to the multiclass case, naturally takes us to the multi-way cut (or multi-terminal cut — see Costa et al. [2005]) problem. Given a graph and a list of terminal nodes, find a set of edges such that, once removed, each terminal belongs to a different component. The goal is to minimize the sum of the weights of the removed edges. Unfortunately, the multi-way cut problem is MAX SNP-hard when the number of terminals is bigger than two (Dalhaus et al. [1994]).
